TextEquiv.Unicode: out, shal we judge him to be wel in his
wits which offereth the light of a bur
ning wato, candle or taper for a pre
sen tto the authour and giver of light :
Hee requireth other manner of light
at our handes, and that not smoakie,
but cleare and bright, to wit the light
of the minde. But a man may com
monly see in these dayes, a great part
of the worshipping of God to be repo
sed in the offering of candels, which
thing is cleane against the manifest
truth,
Amongst other instruments of the
Church, bels are reckoned uppe, which
at these dayes are unto us, as in olde
time trumpets were unto the people of
God For they serue to cal the congre
gation together, and they are numbred
among tokens and warnings. About
bels there is a wonderful superstition,
They are christened by bishops: and it
is thought ye they have polver to put
away any great tempest. In the olde
time men were slirred up to prayer by
theringing of them, what time any
fore tempest did riserbut now the very
ringing of bels, byreason of their cose
cratio seemeth to have a peculiar kind
of vertue in it. Tho ean but marvel
and be astonied at this extreme blind
nesse: Moreover they use belles to be
wayle the dead. Al which things are
superstitious, and , utterly to bee con
temned: ymum or id124s 1: Tmmar
For somuch as thetrue use of the
church goods consisteth in those things
which we reckoned up before, it follo
weth that the abuse therof must needs
be in the rftraries, whether we do of
fend in dne kind or im many. Justice &
equity is to be kept in these as well as
in all other things,
Te ought not to take from one ma
& give to another, but wee must give
untoevery one that which is his own.

out, shal we judge him to be wel in his wits which offereth the light of a bur ning wato, candle or taper for a pre sen tto the authour and giver of light : Hee requireth other manner of light at our handes, and that not smoakie, but cleare and bright, to wit the light of the minde. But a man may com monly see in these dayes, a great part of the worshipping of God to be repo sed in the offering of candels, which thing is cleane against the manifest truth, Amongst other instruments of the Church, bels are reckoned uppe, which at these dayes are unto us, as in olde time trumpets were unto the people of God For they serue to cal the congre gation together, and they are numbred among tokens and warnings. About bels there is a wonderful superstition, They are christened by bishops: and it is thought ye they have polver to put away any great tempest. In the olde time men were slirred up to prayer by theringing of them, what time any fore tempest did riserbut now the very ringing of bels, byreason of their cose cratio seemeth to have a peculiar kind of vertue in it. Tho ean but marvel and be astonied at this extreme blind nesse: Moreover they use belles to be wayle the dead. Al which things are superstitious, and , utterly to bee con temned: ymum or id124s 1: Tmmar For somuch as thetrue use of the church goods consisteth in those things which we reckoned up before, it follo weth that the abuse therof must needs be in the rftraries, whether we do of fend in dne kind or im many. Justice & equity is to be kept in these as well as in all other things, Te ought not to take from one ma & give to another, but wee must give untoevery one that which is his own.
Therefore we may not take any thing
from the poore and give it to the mini
sters of ye church : neither is their por
tion and necessaries to be taken from
them, that the poore may live thereof,
The holy scripture giveth one portion
of the church goods to the ministers of
the Church : and the same Churche
willeth us to give unto the poore their
part. Therefore if bishops or ministers
of the Church do challenge unto them
selves all the church goods, & give not
unto the poore their partes due unto
them, they defile themselves with sa
criledge.
If the ministers do not challege un
to thefelves al the goods of the Church,
& yet doe take unjustly more than ey
ther it becommeth them, or than neede
requireth, or otherwise than the decree
of God and the Apostles doth allower
or else if they spende unthriftily that
portion due unto the, they grievously
offende. But they sinne greatly, yea,
most horribly if they wast the goodes
of the poore, in hunting, dicing, drin
king and ryoting, whore hunting, or
else in warrefare, :and in the meane
time: have no regarde of the Church,
neyther care whut is done there, or
how.
But if a just and good portion fall
unto the poore, perhaps there will bee
a fault in this poynt, in the Steward
or Almonar through favour or ha
tred, that they that have most neede
shall have nothing, and the least wor
thie shall have most, then in this case
there is also great offence committed
through filthy abuse. But of all abu
ses, that seemeth to be the shamefullest
which is nowe a daies almost com
monly used. Wee bestow great costes
and chareges upon stones and stockes,
that is to say uppon idols voyde of all
understandingbut there is no regard

Therefore we may not take any thing from the poore and give it to the mini sters of ye church : neither is their por tion and necessaries to be taken from them, that the poore may live thereof, The holy scripture giveth one portion of the church goods to the ministers of the Church : and the same Churche willeth us to give unto the poore their part. Therefore if bishops or ministers of the Church do challenge unto them selves all the church goods, & give not unto the poore their partes due unto them, they defile themselves with sa criledge. If the ministers do not challege un to thefelves al the goods of the Church, & yet doe take unjustly more than ey ther it becommeth them, or than neede requireth, or otherwise than the decree of God and the Apostles doth allower or else if they spende unthriftily that portion due unto the, they grievously offende. But they sinne greatly, yea, most horribly if they wast the goodes of the poore, in hunting, dicing, drin king and ryoting, whore hunting, or else in warrefare, :and in the meane time: have no regarde of the Church, neyther care whut is done there, or how. But if a just and good portion fall unto the poore, perhaps there will bee a fault in this poynt, in the Steward or Almonar through favour or ha tred, that they that have most neede shall have nothing, and the least wor thie shall have most, then in this case there is also great offence committed through filthy abuse. But of all abu ses, that seemeth to be the shamefullest which is nowe a daies almost com monly used. Wee bestow great costes and chareges upon stones and stockes, that is to say uppon idols voyde of all understandingbut there is no regard
